title: If you don't monetize your YouTube video, can you use anyone's copyright music? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, you can’t. Under U.S. copyright law (Title 17 U.S. Code), it’s illegal to distribute copyrighted content for which you’re not the intellectual property rights owner. It is also strictly prohibited by YouTube since it’s a violation of their Terms of Service and Community Guidelines. Whether you monetize is irrelevant (under Google’s AdSense policies, monetizing content that doesn’t belong to you is also a violation of their TOS, but even if you don’t monetize, it’s still illegal to distribute content that isn’t yours unless you have the owner’s permission. Simply put, it’s theft of someone else’s intellectual property…whether you make money off of it or not. When copyrighted content is found in your YouTube video through their ContentID system, it will automatically flag it and send you a “matched content notification” and apply whatever remedy the content owner has specified: The rights owner can choose to (1) strip the infringing audio, (2) block the video altogether, or (3) monetize it (by running adds on it or providing a link to purchase the music).[1] The rights owner is also notified of the violation and the action taken, and they have the option to submit a formal takedown notice under the D.M.C.A., which will result in a copyright strike on your acccount (three strikes and your account is terminated).[2] [3] Instead of stealing others’ copyrighted music, you should either: Obtain permission or negotiate a license for use of the music (typically you would work through a rights management company like ASCAP, BMI, or SESAC for this).Use music that’s offered through a Creative Commons license (it’s technically copyrighted but the CC licenses it for such use as long as you follow the terms of the license).Use soundtracks from YouTube’s Audio Library of permitted copyright-free music.Use soundtracks from one of the YouTube channels which specializes in providing copyright-free music (such as Audio Library – No Copyright Music or Music for creators).Alternatively, you can look up the music policies for that artist and song on YouTube to see in advance how they typically handle infringements. Note, however, that just because they say it’s allowed and they’ll monetize does NOT necessarily mean it’s OK (it’s still copyright infringement and it’s still illegal), but it means they’ve decided for now that it isn’t worth it to pursue violations in court and would rather just monetize your use. Keep in mind, however, that since you’re knowingly using their content without their permission, the rights owner can rescind that allowance at any time (which is particularly likely if your video becomes popular, goes viral, gets publicity, reflects poorly on them, or otherwise becomes an issue). Footnotes[1] What is a Content ID claim?[2] Copyright Infringement Notification Requirements[3] Copyright strike basics

In general, whether you’re monetizing or not doesn't matter: If the music isn't licensed for use in your video you shouldn't use it. Same goes for images, sound effects, fonts etc. Having said that, YouTube has a handy-dandy ‘music policies’ tool [1]where you can search for copyrighted music and see the policies that are in place for said music. Here you can see whether you can use the music, and if you can, under what conditions. The policies typically look like this: If you use this songPlaybackViewable worldwide MonetizationYou can't monetize your video If you include a song with these policies in your video, everyone can see it but you won’t be able to monetize it. (Pretty straightforward) But also, ads may also be placed on the video by the owner of the music. Some songs will look like this: If you use this songPlaybackViewable everywhere except Germany MonetizationYou can't monetize your video There’s a licensing organisation in Germany called GEMA that has a strong say in what can and can’t be played in their region. It’s the reason that German viewers can’t watch YouTube livestreams; you could unexpectedly start jammin’ to some copyrighted music mid-livestream. Though this may not be of any concern to you if you don’t have a German audience. Other songs will look like this: This song is not available for use in your YouTube videos. If you use this song, your video may be blocked or muted. Clear and to the point.Without getting in contact with the music label and licensing the song - using this song in your video would result in some lackluster silence in your videos. This policy will often apply to newly-released songs and the policy may change later down the line. tl;drOnly if it is in the YouTube music policies and it states that it can be used.
